CLUE: Did the Iliad log out these flowers?
OUTPUT: ['Tulipa (Tulips - though they are not literally logged out, tulips could be symbolically absent if one imagines a garden without them).', "Narcissus (Narcis is the Latin name for the plant associated with self-admiration; metaphorically, it could represent something that 'logs out' itself.)", 'Helianthus (Sunflowers - again symbolic, as they turn away from their source of life: the sun).', "Rosa (Roses - though roses don't log out, one might imagine a rose garden missing its central beauty if left unattended.)", 'Lysimachia (Little lisp-producing plant - not an actual flower that logs out, but playful language used here).', "Orchis (Orchids - some orchids are known to bloom for only a short period and then 'close off,' metaphorically logging out.)", 'Anemone (Anemones - often associated with transience as they typically have a brief blooming phase.)', 'Iris (Irises - sometimes called the "Practical Plant" because of their ability to endure various conditions, though not literally \'logging out\'.)', "Nymphaea (Water lilies - which rise and fall with the water levels but don't log out in a technological sense.)", 'Bellis perennis (Daisy - represents innocence or simplicity; one might imagine them as naturally turning away if neglected.)', 'Maranta leuconeura (Prayer plant - its leaves fold down at night, but this is not the same as logging out.)', "Allium sativum (Garlic - metaphorically speaking, 'logs out' by being left in storage.)", "Artemisia (Sagebrush - it thrives and survives with little care but doesn't log out.)", "Ceropegia woodii (String of hearts; the vines can die back during dry periods, which might be seen as a 'logout.' However, this is not digital logging.)", 'Cactus species (Certain cacti flower and then remain dormant for long periods - could symbolize temporary disengagement similar to logging out.)', "Camellia sinensis (Tea plant; leaves are harvested periodically but don't 'log out' themselves.)", "Lavandula angustifolia (Lavender - it doesn't log out, but its scent can fade or diminish if not regularly tended to.)", 'Salvia officinalis (Sage) - while sage continues to thrive without attention, one might imagine a garden where the sage has been neglected and is no longer as prominent.', 'Aeonium arboreum var', "Vaccinium myrtillus (Bilberry - it grows abundantly but wouldn't 'log out'; used metaphorically for a garden with no bilberries)."]
